Article Title: The evolution of India’s telecom landscape in 2025 and the way forward
Article Text:
Fixed wireless access : Redefining broadband delivery



Enterprise 5G: From pilots to scale

Software-led, programmable networks

AI for networks, networks for AI

Policy, skills and the road ahead

Conclusion

By: Nitin Bansal, Managing Director, India Head-Networks, Market Area South East Asia, Oceania, and India at Ericsson





India’s telecom sector in 2025 marks a transition from nationwide 5G deployment to a driving focus on value creation, monetisation and intelligent networks. Connectivity is no longer the end goal; it has become the platform on which India’s digital economy is being built. With 5G now firmly embedded across urban centres and expanding steadily into semi-urban and rural corridors, the sector is redefining its role as a strategic enabler of economic growth, enterprise transformation and inclusive digital access central to the vision of Viksit Bharat 2047.India has emerged as one of the world’s fastest growing 5G markets, driven by rapid consumer adoption and an unparalleled appetite for mobile data. The latest industry reports project that India will approach one billion 5G subscriptions by 2030, with 5G accounting for nearly 79 percent of total mobile subscriptions by that time. This momentum is being fuelled by immersive video, cloud-based applications, gaming and increasingly sophisticated digital experiences.One of the most consequential developments of the year has been the rise of 5G Fixed Wireless Access (FWA) as a mainstream broadband alternative.FWA has demonstrated that high-speed connectivity does not need to be constrained by the pace and economics of fibre deployment. By delivering fibre-like speeds wirelessly, FWA is transforming broadband access for homes and small businesses, particularly in fast-growing suburbs, smaller towns and areas where last-mile connectivity has traditionally been a challenge.By 2025, FWA connections have scaled rapidly, signalling a structural shift in India’s broadband model. This has meaningful implications for digital inclusion - enabling access to online education, telehealth, remote work and digital entrepreneurship. More importantly, it reinforces the idea that wireless technologies will play a central role in bridging India’s digital divide.Enterprise adoption of 5G reached an inflection point in 2025. What began as isolated pilots has started translating into scalable deployments across manufacturing, logistics, utilities, mining, ports and public services. Enterprises are increasingly investing in private 5G networks and edge computing to improve productivity, enhance safety, automate operations and gain real-time visibility into complex processes.Industry showcases and deployments during the year have highlighted how AI-enabled automation, digital twins, remote operations and mission-critical communications are becoming commercially viable at scale. This signals a fundamental shift for the telecom sector from being a connectivity provider to becoming a strategic partner in enterprise digital transformation.Perhaps the most defining change in 2025 has been the transition toward software-driven, cloud-native and programmable networks. Telecom infrastructure is increasingly being modernised through virtualised architectures, AI-based optimisation and end-to-end automation. These capabilities are critical as networks become denser, traffic volumes surge and energy efficiency becomes a business imperative.At the same time, the exposure of network capabilities through open APIs is transforming networks into platforms. Functions such as quality-on-demand, security, location intelligence and device insights are being made accessible to developers and enterprises, enabling the creation of new applications across financial services, mobility, gaming, logistics and industrial automation. This programmability is laying the foundation for an entirely new innovation ecosystem around connectivity.AI is becoming essential to managing the complexity of modern networks - enabling intent-driven operations, autonomous decision-making, improved reliability and lower total cost of ownership. On the other, the next generation of AI applications - personal AI assistants, real-time analytics, immersive experiences and intelligent machines - will depend on high-performing networks with low latency, strong uplink capabilities and edge computing.Robust, intelligent connectivity is required for mass-scale AI adoption and telecom networks are evolving into the invisible engine that powers India’s AI-led digital future.Progressive policy frameworks, spectrum planning and emerging satellite connectivity initiatives continue to strengthen India’s telecom foundation, particularly for remote and strategically important regions. Equally critical is the focus on skills and ecosystem readiness. Investments in 5G, AI and software capabilities - supported by industry-academia collaboration - are creating a future-ready talent base that will be vital as India prepares for the transition to 6G.India’s telecom sector in 2025 stands at the threshold of a new era defined not by expansion alone, but by intelligence, programmability and purpose. By embracing software-led networks, enterprise innovation, FWA-driven inclusion and the powerful convergence of AI and connectivity, the industry is building long-term value for the economy. As India looks toward 20s30 and beyond, telecom will remain a cornerstone of its ambition to emerge as a leading global digital economy.
Article Summary: India’s telecom sector in 2025 marks a transition from nationwide 5G deployment to a driving focus on value creation, monetisation and intelligent networks. Connectivity is no longer the end goal; it has become the platform on which India's digital economy is being built. By delivering fibre-like speeds wirelessly, FWA is transforming broadband access for homes and small businesses.

Article Title: PwC’s global chairman Mohamed Kande to CEOs: More than 50% companies are getting nothing out of their AI investments; so don't forget the ...
Article Text:
PwC global chairman: CEOs face a new kind of challenge

PwC global chairman: AI adoption rises, results still limited

Confidence gap among business leaders





PwC global chairman Mohamed Kande has said that a majority of companies are not seeing results from their artificial intelligence (AI) investments because they are missing basic groundwork. Speaking to Fortune on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum meeting in Davos, Switzerland, Kande highlighted a PwC survey which says that 56% companies are getting “nothing” out of AI, even as spending and adoption rise sharply. During the interaction, Kande said the role of CEOs has changed significantly, with leaders now expected to manage existing businesses, transform operations, and build new models at the same time. According to Kande, AI has become a key pressure point in this shift.Kande said the job of a CEO has changed more in the past year than in the previous 25 years. He explained that business leaders are now expected to run current operations, make changes in real time, and prepare for future business models simultaneously. He said this three-part responsibility is something he has not seen before in his career.“This is one of the most testing moments for leaders,” Kande told Fortune.He added that while the pace of change is creating uncertainty, similar periods have occurred in the past, including during major economic and industrial shifts.PwC’s 29th global CEO survey, based on responses from 4,454 CEOs across 95 countries and regions, shows a wide gap between AI adoption and outcomes. Kande said companies have moved from debating whether to use AI to actively deploying it. “Nobody is asking that question anymore. Everybody’s going for it,” he said.However, the survey found that only 10% to 12% of companies report gains in revenue or cost savings from AI. At the same time, 56% said they are not seeing any benefit. Kande said the issue is not the technology itself but weak execution.He said companies that are seeing results have focused on clean data, clear processes, and proper oversight. “Somehow AI moves so fast … that people forgot that the adoption of technology, you have to go to the basics,” Kande said.Kande also pointed to a gap in confidence among CEOs. While many leaders say they feel positive about the global economy, fewer are confident about growing their own businesses. PwC’s survey shows that only three in ten CEOs expect revenue growth over the next 12 months, the lowest level in five years.Kande said this uncertainty is also affecting how companies think about talent and careers, as AI takes over routine tasks. He said traditional entry-level learning models may need to change as a result.Kande said leaders should look at long-term trends rather than short-term disruptions. “I’m an optimist,” he said, adding that understanding change is key to dealing with it.
Article Summary: PwC global chairman Mohamed Kande said 56% companies are getting “nothing’ out of AI. He said the issue is not the technology itself but weak execution. Only 10% to 12% of companies report gains in revenue or cost savings from AI.

Article Title: Google exec ‘calls out’ the No. 1 problem that American technology companies face and Chinese don’t have to
Article Text:
How Google is tackling its ‘energy’ problems

Calls for US energy investment





Google’s senior executive has now warned that the US electrical transmission system is now the single biggest challenge facing American technology companies. Creating years-long delays in connecting new data centers to the grid. As reported by Reuters, speaking at an American Enterprise Institute ever, Marsden Hanna, Google’s global head of sustainability and climate policy said the transmission barriers are slowing down the expansion of critical infrastructure.“Transmission barriers are the number one challenge we’re seeing on the grid,” Hanna said. “We had one utility who told us 12 years to study the interconnection timeline, which is sort of wild, but that’s what we’re seeing.” On the other hand, Chinese technology companies do not face such prolonged bottlenecks, giving them a competitive edge in scaling data center capacity.To address these delays, Hanna urged policymakers to accelerate the approval process for new high-voltage transmission lines. Meanwhile, she also listed out Google’s strategy to power its data centres.Google calls it 'co-location' strategy wherein it plans to build data centres adjacent to existing power plants.By plugging directly into the source, Google can theoretically avoid the decade-long wait for a grid connection, bypassing the congested transmission system.“That's the strategy we're pursuing with colocation and our hope is that these can eventually be grid-connected resources,” Hanna said.The global electricity demand is said to increase by 30% by 2035 and it is largely driven by the rapid growth of data centers. Their share of total power consumption is expected to more than double, from 1.5% today to 3.5%, as artificial intelligence adoption accelerates.Earlier this month, one of America’s biggest investor Michael Burry urged the US President Donald Trump and Vice President JD Vance to fast-track a $1 trillion nuclear power and grid expansion plan. In a post on social media platform X (formerly known as Twitter) Burry argued that deploying small nuclear reactors nationwide and building a hardened national grid is the only way for the US to meet the increasing electricity demand which is driven by artificial intelligence. Burry also feels that this is only way in which we can hope to keep up with China, stressing that abundant energy is important for long-term national security and managing US debt.
Article Summary: Marsden Hanna, Google’s global head of sustainability and climate policy said the transmission barriers are slowing down the expansion of critical infrastructure. Hanna urged policymakers to accelerate the approval process for new high-voltage transmission lines. Google calls it 'co-location' strategy wherein it plans to build data centres adjacent to existing power plants.

Article Title: Tesla CEO Elon Musk: We know Twitter’s algorithm is dumb, but at least ...
Article Text:
'US Benefited Immensely From Indians', Says Tesla CEO Elon Musk, Warns US Against Scrapping H-1B

Elon Musk keeps promise that he made in 2023





Tesla CEO Elon Musk has admitted limitations in social media platform X (formerly Twitter). In a post, the tech billionaire emphasized the platform’s real-time transparency as a key differentiator from competitors like Meta and TikTok. “We know the algorithm is dumb and needs massive improvements, but at least you can see us struggle to make it better in real-time and with transparency,” Musk wrote, adding “No other social media companies do this”.He was responding to a post by the official handle of X Engineering which announced the open-sourcing of X's new recommendation algorithm on January 20, 2026, fulfilling Elon Musk's January 10 promise to release the code powering organic and ad post recommendations every four weeks with developer notes.In a post earlier this month, the X owner said that the company “will make the new X algorithm, including all code used to determine what organic and advertising posts are recommended to users, open source in 7 days”.“This will be repeated every 4 weeks, with comprehensive developer notes, to help you understand what changed,” he further added.Elon Musk first promised to make X algorithm open-sourced in 2023. That year, a version was made available, but it was never updated.In order to record ongoing changes, the company now intends to release updated code and thorough developer notes every four weeks.The decision to make the algorithm open source comes as X faces pressure from regulators about content moderation and algorithmic bias. The European Commission recently extended a data retention order for the platform through 2026, while authorities in France and the UK have raised concerns about illegal content being shared. By making the code public, the company wants to let outside developers and researchers review the system and suggest technical improvements.
Article Summary: Elon Musk has admitted limitations in social media platform X (formerly Twitter) The tech billionaire emphasized the platform’s real-time transparency as a key differentiator. He was responding to a post by the official handle of X Engineering which announced the open-sourcing of X's new recommendation algorithm on January 20, 2026.
